Synthesizing efficient and selective green ideal catalysts has been an increasingly critical, yet unsolved, issue for the ammonia synthesis industry, hindering the growing global demand for environmental protection and energy efficiency. Electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction (eNRR) is a promising technology for low-energy ammonia synthesis. However, designing efficient electrocatalysts for NRR remains challenging. The emergence of graphene-like substrates offers exciting prospects for addressing this challenge and facilitating single-atom catalysts in eNRR. Here, we report the innovative selection of a recently synthesized two-dimensional biphenyl network (2D BPN) compound as a substrate. Its excellent conductivity and porosity enable stable transition metal atoms (TMs) support for constructing eNRR electrocatalysts. we evaluated the feasibility of 23 TMs anchored on BPN for eNRR by high-throughput first-principles calculations. Through a systematic five-step strategy, we identified several single-atom catalysts (SACs) with potential for eNRR, including Mo@BPN, V@BPN, W@BPN, and Re@BPN. Among them, Mo@BPN exhibited the best balance in the adsorption of key reaction intermediates (e.g., N2H and NH3) and demonstrated a low limiting potential (-0.37 V). In addition, the underlying mechanism of NRR activity was elucidated by analyzing the extrinsic patterns revealed through the screened catalysts. A triangular volcano diagram, incorporating the initial protonation step, adsorption free energy, and final protonation step, revealed the NRR activity trend. Overall, this study provides a solid theoretical foundation and valuable guidance for future experimental exploration of efficient electrocatalysts for ammonia synthesis on BPN. Crucial insights into the theoretical design of efficient electrocatalysts are also offered. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biphenyl network Density functional theory Single-atom catalysts Nitrogen fixation Electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ammonia has long played an indispensable role across various industries, serving purposes such as fertilizer production, industrial chemical synthesis, and energy storage [1,2]. Currently, most global ammonia production relies on the industrial Haber-Bosch process, which has significant drawbacks, including harsh reaction conditions, high energy consumption, and the emission of greenhouse gases (CO2) [3–5]. These issues sharply contrast with contemporary societal goals of achieving carbon peak and neutrality. Therefore, it is crucial to develop cleaner and greener ammonia synthesis technologies to replace the Haber-Bosch process. Among the ammonia synthesis methods, the electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction (eNRR) has attracted significant attention due to its ability to proceed at ambient temperature and pressure, using environmentally friendly and energy-saving raw materials [6–8]. The nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) is considered a promising alternative for ammonia synthesis. However, challenges such as low faradaic efficiency, low ammonia yield, weak adsorption of N2 molecules, and competitive hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) limit its large-scale industrial application [9,10]. Thus, developing stable, highly active, highly selective, and low-cost electrocatalysts is vital to advancing sustainable electrocatalytic ammonia synthesis. An efficient catalyst in an electrocatalytic reaction can accelerate reaction rates, lower activation energy barriers, enhance product selectivity and reduce costs [11,12]. Currently, available electrocatalysts mostly rely on expensive and rare noble or transition metal catalysts, which improve the efficiency of NRR to some extent. However, high costs and low atomic utilization present significant obstacles to practical applications [6,13,14]. In recent years, single-atom catalysts (SACs), primarily composed of single transition metal atoms (TMs) anchored on supports, have garnered significant attention due to their structural characteristics [8,15–18]. These characteristics provide active sites with unsaturated coordination, the highest atomic utilization, and efficient, low-cost performance. Specifically, by tuning the interactions between single TMs and their supports, the local electronic structure can be optimized, enhancing the selectivity for adsorption and desorption of different molecules, thereby achieving high catalytic efficiency [8,19–22]. With continuous advancements in experimental characterization and synthesis techniques, many SACs have been experimentally prepared for use in ORR, OER, HER, and NRR reactions [4,23–26]. It is noteworthy that SACs may be prone to atomic aggregation due to strong d-d interactions and high surface energy, which can significantly reduce their structural stability and catalytic activity [20,27–29]. Therefore, identifying suitable supports that can firmly anchor transition metal atoms through coordination or covalent bonds while maintaining their thermodynamic and chemical stability is crucial [30]. Graphene and its derivatives have been widely studied as substrates for SACs in recent years due to their unique structures and properties [9,28,31,32]. The Biphenylene network (BPN), an emerging non-benzenoid carbon allotrope with an sp² hybridized structure, comprises four-, six-, and eight-membered rings (Fig. 1 (a)). The distinctive multi-ring structure of BPN enhances its potential as a substrate for SACs [33]. Recently, J. Michael Gottfried and his colleagues [34] successfully synthesized biphenylene networks using a bottom-up approach and demonstrated their metallic properties, which are consistent with our calculations of BPN's total density of states (Fig. 1(b)). In comparison to graphene, BPN exhibits superior chemical and thermal stability as well as a higher number of surface active sites, underscoring its potential as a catalyst and a substrate for metal atom catalysts [35,36]. Wu et al. [37] recently studied boron-doped BPN as a substrate for lithium atom adsorption and found that Li-doped BPN is a carbon material with significant hydrogen storage potential. This potential is primarily attributed to BPN's high chemical and thermal stability, which prevents Li aggregation on the surface, thus enhancing hydrogen storage capacity. Similarly, Yeh et al. [38] investigated BPN's catalytic performance in the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), finding that the four-membered rings in BPN nanosheets exhibit strong catalytic activity towards O₂, outperforming graphene. Furthermore, calculations of BPN's differential charge density (DCD) (Fig. 1(c)) reveal that electrons primarily accumulate between C-C atoms, indicating strong covalent bonding and increased stability of the reaction substrates. Therefore, leveraging BPN's inherent thermal stability, metallic properties, and potential catalytic performance, combined with different transition metal single atoms and employing rational screening strategies, can further explore SACs structures with high selectivity and catalytic activity. In this study, we performed comprehensive density functional theory (DFT) calculations to evaluate the potential catalytic performance and selectivity of TMs catalysts supported on BPN sheets for NRR. Through a five-step strategy, we ultimately identified SACs with high activity and selectivity. By analyzing the observed external trends, we summarized the intrinsic nature of their catalytic activity. Finally, focusing on the catalyst with the best performance, Mo@BPN, we employed methods such as charge difference density (CDD), Bader charge transfer, and bond length variations to reveal the adsorption and activation mechanisms of N₂ on the SACs surface, and explored the possible NRR reaction pathways. Our research findings not only elucidate the specific electrocatalytic performance of BPN materials supporting SACs for the NRR but also offer valuable insights for the further development of efficient electrocatalysts aimed at sustainable ammonia production. 2 Methods All structure optimization, single point energies, electronic property analysis, and free energies were performed based on the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) under DFT calculations [28,39]. Projection Augmented Wave (PAW) pseudopotentials were used to handle the interactions between core electrons and ions, while Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange-correlation generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was used to handle the exchange-correlation energy [29,40,41]. Van der Waals interactions between small molecules and substrates were considered using the Grimme method (DFT-D3). The cut-off energy of 500 eV was used for all calculations. For all biphenyl network substrates, a 3 × 3 × 1 supercell was used. Subsequently, the TMs were loaded and their stable structures were probed (Fig. 1(d)) and finally the catalysts were formed. To avoid interactions between the periodic structures, the lattice constant in the vacuum layer direction was set to 20 Å. The Monkhorst-Pack mesh for structural optimization and electronic characterization are 3 × 3 × 1, and 7 × 7 × 1, respectively. The convergence criterion for energy was 10−5 eV and the force convergence criterion is -0.01 eV/Å. The Bader charge was used to analyze the charge change of the reaction intermediates. An implicit solvation model [42] has been employed to simulate the realistic conditions of the NRR in an aqueous solution. The adsorption energy of N2 molecule is calculated by the following equation [43]: (1) E a d s = E t o t − E B P N − E N 2 where E a d s denotes the adsorption energy of N2, E t o t denotes the total energy of N2 adsorbed on the catalyst, E B P N is the energy of the biphenyl network and E N 2 denotes the energy of a single N2 molecule. Based on the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model of Nørskov et al. [44], the Gibbs free energy for each protonation step in the electrocatalytic process is obtained by the following equation: (2) Δ G = Δ E + Δ E Z P E − T Δ S + Δ G U + Δ G p H Δ E is the reaction energy between two adjacent steps, Δ E Z P E is the change in zero-point energy, T is the temperature (298.15 K), Δ S is the change in entropy, Δ G U = − n e U , where n is the number of transferred electrons and U is the applied potential. Δ G p H = k B T × l n 10 × p H , where k B is Boltzmann's constant and we set the value is zero. The limiting potential can be obtained from this equation [13,26,45]: (3) U l i m i t i n g = − Δ G m a x / e − where Δ G m a x is the free energy change of the decisive step in the NRR. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Geometric structure of TMs@BPN Similar to graphene, the sp2-hybridized BPN monolayer also exhibits π-π conjugation behavior. This conjugation arises from the surface-distributed pores and the abundant, uniformly coordinated carbon sites, forming an π-π conjugated framework that creates conductive pathways, thereby enhancing electronic conductivity and mechanical stability. After confirming the significant potential of BPN as an excellent catalyst support, the construction of TMs@BPN catalysts was undertaken. The periodic multi-ring structure of BPN, consisting of four-, six-, and eight-membered rings, provides ample space to anchor TMs atoms, preventing their migration and aggregation. Potential nine sites (Fig. 1(a)) were considered to determine the energetically most favorable anchoring sites for TMs atoms, which were considered to include 23 commercial transition metals from 3d, 4d, and 5d orbitals (Fig. 1(d)). The most stable structures and energy diagrams after structural optimization of the 207 structures are presented in Fig. S1 and Table S1, indicating that most TMs atoms are most stably adsorbed on the four-membered rings, with a few exceptions. This finding is consistent with Luo et al.'s study [36] on the HER, which identified four-membered rings as the most stable catalytic sites. The electrocatalytic activity and cycling stability of the catalysts are critical for the industrialization of SACs such as TMs@BPN. Strong binding of individual TMs atoms on the BPN surface is essential to prevent TM aggregation. Therefore, we calculated the binding energies of TMs on monolayer BPN to assess the stability of the SACs using the formula: E b = E T M s @ B P N − E B P N − E T M s in which E B P N and E T M s are the energies of the TMs atom and BPN, respectively, and E T M s @ B P N is the total energy of the TMs adsorbed on BPN. Larger negative binding energies represent stronger interaction forces between TMs atoms and BPNs, and more stable catalysts can exist. As shown in Table 1 , the binding energies float between -6.74 and -1.48 eV, which is much lower than zero, which indicates that all TMs can be stably anchored to BPNs, in which further suggests that constructing TMs@BPN SACs is a potentially feasible strategy. The redistribution of charges between the substrate and TMs is crucial evidence for the stability of TMs@BPN. Bader charge analysis reveals significant interactions between the substrate and TMs atoms. Except for a few TMs (such as Ag, Pt, and Au), most TMs atoms show a noticeable electron transfer from the TMs to the BPN substrate. Some reports indicate that positively charged TMs atoms can act as active centers and anchor sites in potential SACs, which would weaken the adsorption ability of protons, making it promising to capture and activate small molecules, and to promote the high efficiency and selectivity of the reaction. Consequently, TMs@BPN is expected to act as an N2 adsorption site and central activator in the NRR, improving both the activity and selectivity of the reaction. 3.2 Screening of TMs@BPN Based on the potential support sites on the BPN surface, 23 catalysts have been identified for screening efficient and promising NRR electrocatalysts. Generally, the limiting potential is employed to assess the activity of NRR catalysts. However, NRR is a complex six-electron reaction involving various reaction pathways such as distal, alternating, enzymatic, and consecutive mechanisms. Evaluating 23 catalysts would require structural optimization of 368 intermediates, which demands substantial computational resources and time. Therefore, it is essential to utilize some simple evaluation strategies to screen out promising and efficient catalysts from among the many candidates. According to previous research experience [27], a clear five-step strategy is proposed: (1) Eb < 0 eV, to measure the stability of the catalyst; (2) ensuring that N2 can chemisorb on BPN-supported TMs with ΔG*N2 < -0.3 eV, which ensures sufficient activation of N2 and is crucial for the NRR reaction; (3) the potential limiting step for NRR, the first protonation ΔG*N2-NNH < 0.55 eV, guarantees that the catalyst's catalytic activity surpasses that of pure transition metal catalysts; (4) competitive HER reaction, to keep high selectivity of NRR catalysts, the absolute value of ΔGHER for each catalyst should be greater than the Gibbs free energy change of the first protonation step; (5) the ΔG*NH2-NH3 value should be lower than 0.55 eV, to ensure low energy loss and prevent catalyst poisoning. Focusing on the screening steps, we first investigated the adsorption of N2 molecules on TMs@BPN, in which two initial adsorption models, side-on and end-on, were mainly considered. The changes in free energy for N2 species adsorbed on TMs@BPN are shown in Fig. 2 (a). Clearly, most catalysts, except TMs@BPN (TMs = Cr, Mn, Cu, Ag, Au), exhibit more negativeΔG*N2 (ΔG*N2 < -0.3 eV), which indicates that all of these catalysts can capture and activate the N2 molecules effectively. Meanwhile, we found that the bond lengths of N2 molecules on these candidates were significantly prolonged (LN-N > 1.13 Å, see Fig. 2 (b)). Notably, catalysts such as V, Nb, Mo, Ta, W, Re, and Os@BPN showed even more significant NN bond elongation in both side on and end on adsorption structures, further confirming the excellent adsorption and substantial activation of N2 molecules. Generally, the first-step protonation does not proceed spontaneously and requires an energy input to activate the stable NN bond. Moreover, previous studies [14] have shown that the first protonation step can serve as a screening criterion for high-performance NRR catalysts. Therefore, we calculated the ΔG values for the first hydrogenation step (*N2+e−→*NNH) on TMs@BPN sheets to evaluate the catalytic activity of SACs and further screen for suitable NRR SACs. The calculation results are shown in Fig. 2(c). We can see that, except for W@BPN, Hf@BPN, Zr@BPN Ta@BPN and Ir@BPN, the ΔG values for side-on are lower than those of end-on adsorption modes, indicating that the side-on adsorption modes are thermodynamically more favorable for the form of *NNH intermediates. This finding is consistent with the pattern observed by He et al. [41] in their study of SACs on P3C for NRR catalysis. By screening the condition ΔG*N2-NNH < 0.55 eV, we screened TMs@BPN (TMs = Ti, Mo, V, Ta, W, and Re) low energy cost and highly catalytic catalysts with free energies required for the first step of protonation floating in the range of 0.10-0.40 eV, which suggests that they are sufficiently activated. Next, we considered the competitive reaction of HER for these promising ammonia production candidates to evaluate the selectivity of TMs@BPN catalysts. A strong HER reaction could occupy the adsorption sites of the catalyst and affect subsequent protonation reactions. To prevent HER from dominating the catalytic process, the ΔGH* of HER should be far from 0 eV, meaning that the absolute value of the Gibbs free energy of the adsorbed H should be greater than ΔG*N2-NNH. and ∆G*N2 < ∆G*H (Fig. S2). That ensures that SACs have preferential adsorption, activation, and reaction advantages for N2. Among the remaining TMs@BPN (TMs = Ti, Mo, V, Ta, W, and Re) candidates, only Ti @BPN and Ta@BPN do not meet the catalytic requirements. To further confirm the catalytic effectiveness of these catalysts, we also verified their catalytic activity through the final protonation step (*NH2 + (H+ + e-)→*NH3), As shown in Fig. 2(d), the range of free energy change for this step is 0.25-0.65 eV, which is significantly lower than the limiting potential of pure transition metal catalysts. Also, the NN bond lengths are activated longer compared to other catalysts. In summary, through a series of screening strategies, only Mo, V, W, and Re @BPN (Fig. S3) were found to satisfy the five-step strategy, thereby being identified as qualified electrocatalysts for nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR). Among them, the Mo@BPN catalyst exhibited the most outstanding potential catalytic performance with free energy changes of 0.26 (end-on) and 0.25 eV for the first and last protonation steps, respectively. To further validate the rationale of the screening strategy, we employed a general screening procedure (substrate stability - nitrogen chemisorption - catalyst activity - catalyst selectivity) to evaluate the selected catalysts systematically. As shown in Fig. S4, after the first-step protonation screening (ΔGN2-NNH < 0.55 eV), Ti@BPN, V@BPN, Mo@BPN, W@BPN, Ta@BPN, and Re@BPN catalysts exhibited strong activity. Subsequently, considering the final protonation step (ΔGNH2-NH3) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) competition, Ti@BPN and Ta@BPN were excluded as potential candidates. Ultimately, V@BPN, Mo@BPN, W@BPN, and Re@BPN were identified as promising NRR electrocatalysts. These findings align closely with the screening conclusions presented in the manuscript, further validating the reliability and robustness of the employed screening methodology. Future research can delve deeper into the catalytic relationships and mechanisms among these catalysts and optimize their performance to expand their applications in clean energy. 3.3 Activity origins and trends As discussed above, the effective adsorption and activation of N2 is a crucial step in the whole NRR reaction, so our eyes were again focused on the interactions between N2 and the catalysts to gain insight into the origin of the activity of these screened catalysts and the microscopic relationship between them. We observe that the adsorption strength between the adsorbate and the catalysts varies with different TM atoms. Fig. 3 (a) shows the relationship between the N2 adsorption free energy (ΔGN2) and the amount of charge transfer (Q), indicating a significant negative correlation (R²=0.94). As the amount of charge transfer increases, the N2 adsorption free energy becomes more negative, thus enhancing the adsorption strength. Interestingly, the trends observed in all SACs were consistent with those of the screened catalysts, thus strengthening the reliability of our conclusions (Fig. S5). Fig. 3(b) further explains the electronic structure mechanism underlying this relationship, illustrating the orbital interaction between the N₂ molecule and the single-atom catalyst (TMs-N2). Specifically, the 2p orbital of N interacts with the d orbital of TMs, forming hybrid orbitals. The hybrid orbitals resulting from N₂ interaction are split into two parts by the Fermi energy level (EF): the occupied 2p bonding orbital and the unoccupied 2π* antibonding orbital. This orbital splitting and interaction determine the electron distribution, thereby contributing to the fixation and activation of N₂. However, does a more negative adsorption free energy always lead to better activation of N₂ molecules? To further explain this issue, we calculated the relationship between COHP (the bonding orbital energy of NN) (Fig. S6) and the free energy of the first hydrogenation step (ΔGN2 - ΔG*NNH). Fig. 3(c) shows a clear negative correlation between the COHP value and the free energy of the first hydrogenation step (R² = 0.84). More negative COHP values indicate stronger NN bonding energy, which facilitates the initial adsorption of N₂ but also increases the energy barrier for the first hydrogenation step, making it more difficult. Specifically, excessively strong NN bonding results in the N₂ molecule being too stable on the catalyst surface, hindering the formation of reaction intermediates and subsequent reaction steps. Thus, while increased adsorption strength is advantageous for the initial adsorption and activation of N2, excessively strong adsorption may adversely affect the subsequent reaction steps. Fig. 3(d) illustrates the relationship between the free energy changes of the first hydrogenation step (ΔG*N2 - ΔG*NNH), the final hydrogenation step (ΔG*NH2-ΔG*NH3), and the N₂ adsorption free energy (ΔG*N2). The figure demonstrates that stronger adsorption free energy does not always correlate with better catalytic performance, as different catalysts exhibit significant variations in the free energy changes for these steps. An ideal catalyst should achieve a balance in these reaction steps to ensure high efficiency throughout the NRR process. Notably, the Mo@BPN electrocatalyst in Fig. 3(d) shows relatively moderate free energy changes in these two steps, with its N₂ adsorption free energy falling within an intermediate range. The primary reason is the moderate energy level of molybdenum's 4d orbitals and the greater dispersion of its d electrons compared to V(3d), W(5d), and Re(5d) orbitals, which makes the molybdenum d-orbitals more susceptible to interactions with reactants and intermediates (Fig. S7). As a result, molybdenum does not encounter product desorption difficulties due to excessively strong N₂ adsorption, nor does it face excessively high energy barriers in the hydrogenation steps. Such balance also indicates that the Mo@BPN electrocatalyst has the potential for high catalytic activity and low limiting potential in N₂ adsorption and hydrogenation steps, making it a more promising NRR electrocatalyst. Therefore, the comprehensive consideration of the adsorption strength of N2 and the free energy changes in each reaction step can be better screened and designed for efficient NRR catalysts. 3.4 Mo@BPN reaction pathway and activity origin for NRR After the discussion of the activity sources and trends of the screened catalysts, we analyzed the activity sources and specific NRR mechanisms taking the potentially optimal electrocatalyst Mo@BPN candidate as a personal example, in an attempt to calculate the corresponding limiting potentials and evaluate the NRR performance. A catalyst's stability is crucial for its catalytic efficiency. To assess the stability of Mo atoms anchored on the BPN surface, we first calculated the migration energy barriers with different orientations. Results showed that the migration energy barriers were 1.38 eV (TS_I) and 1.25 eV (TS_II), respectively (Fig. S8). These relatively high energy barriers indicate that Mo@BPN can stably exist at the four-membered rings site at room temperature, making it a stable catalyst. The activation mechanism of N₂ molecules on Mo@BPN was next analyzed by the change of NN bond length and Bader charge transfer. The adsorption structures are shown in Fig. 4 (a) (b). For side-on and end-on adsorption, the NN bond length significantly elongates from 1.10 Å in the gas phase to 1.21 Å and 1.15 Å, with charge transfers of 0.58 |e| and 0.49 |e|, respectively (Fig. 4(c)(d)). This evidence indicates that the chemically adsorbed N₂ molecules on Mo@BPN are significantly captured and activated, which is beneficial for subsequent reactions. After evaluating the N2 activation on Mo@BPN, we further analyzed the different reaction pathways of NRR in the aqueous environment. As shown in Fig. 4(e), the four possible NRR reaction mechanisms are the distal, alternating, consecutive, and enzymatic pathway. Specifically, the distal and alternating pathways proceed with end-on adsorption of N2, whereas the consecutive and enzymatic pathways occur based on the side-on adsorption. The Gibbs free energy changes and structures for the different NRR pathways are shown in Fig. 5 and S9–S11. When NRR proceeds along the distal and alternating pathways, the N2 molecule first chemisorbs vertically on Mo@BPN. A proton-electron pair (H++e−) then preferentially attacks the distal nitrogen atom of the N2 molecule, forming the *NNH intermediate. This process is non-spontaneous and endothermic, with a required free energy step of 0.37 eV. A notable change during this step is the extension of the N-N bond from 1.16 Å to 1.29 Å. Subsequently, the distal N atom in *NNH undergoes further protonation by another proton-electron pair, forming NNH2, with the N-N bond length increasing to 1.48 Å and the free energy change being -0.51 eV. Continued protonation causes *N-NH2 to dissociate into N and NH3 intermediates, with a free energy change of -0.35 eV. The N species on Mo@BPN then undergoes successive protonation steps (from *N to *NH, then *NH2, and *NH3), with corresponding free energy changes of -0.63 eV, 0.19 eV, and -0.46 eV, respectively. The first protonation step (N2 to NNH) is the potential-determining step (PDS) with a value of -0.37 V. Notably, once the NH3 molecule forms, it ideally should quickly leave the catalyst surface to maintain NRR efficiency. However, the energy change for the *NH3 to NH3(g) process is 1.08 eV, indicating that the desorption of the second NH3 is thermodynamically unfavorable. From an experimental perspective, this step does not involve protonation reactions and does not impact the limiting potential of the reaction. Moreover, these NH3 molecules can be further hydrogenated into NH4 + ions in solution, preventing adsorption on the catalyst surface. For the alternating pathway (Fig. S9), protonation proceeds sequentially on different nitrogen atoms in *NNH until NH3 is fully produced. The intermediates undergo the transitions *N2→*NNH→*NHNH→ *NH2NH→*NH2NH2→*NH2→*NH3, with corresponding free energy changes of 0.37 eV, -0.04 eV, -0.64 eV, 0.94 eV, -0.76 eV, and -1.26 eV. where NH2NH→*NH2NH2 is a PDS step that requires overcoming free energy of 0.94 eV for the reaction to occur. If NRR proceeds via the consecutive and enzymatic mechanisms, proton-electron pairs gradually attack the side-on adsorbed N2 molecule, successively forming two NH3. For the consecutive pathway, the PDS in the free energy diagram for N2 electroreduction is the dissociation of the first NH3 (*NNH2→*N), occurring in the third hydrogenation step with ΔG of 0.73 eV (Fig. S10). For the enzymatic mechanism, the RDS is also the desorption of the first NH3, following the pathway *NH2NH2→*NH2, with ΔG of 0.79 eV (Fig. S11). Overall, the distal mechanism is the most favorable in the complete NRR process with Mo@BPN as the electrocatalyst, where the PDS was the formation of NNH species from adsorbed N2 molecules (end-on mode), corresponding to a limiting potential of -0.37 V. This is similar to the reported limiting potentials of graphene-loaded Mo single-atom catalysts (SACs) tuned via the ligand environment (-0.34 V) [28]. Particularly, the limiting potential required for Mo@BPN (-0.37 V) is about one-third of that for Ru (-0.98 V) compared to the experimental Ru (0001) surface, thus indicating its superior catalytic performance in NRR. 4 Conclusion Designing single-atom catalysts on two-dimensional material substrates for the electrocatalytic synthesis of ammonia is a promising strategy that can significantly enhance catalytic efficiency and reduce production costs. Based on high-throughput DFT calculations, we systematically analyzed the feasibility of 23 TMs anchored on a 2D BPN as NRR electrocatalysts. Our conclusions are as follows: (1) Density of states and charge decomposition reveal that the newly synthesized 2D BPN exhibits excellent metallic properties and stability, demonstrating significant potential as a catalytic substrate. TMs can stably anchor in the four-membered ring pores of the BPN. (2) Employing a five-step strategy, the study systematically analyzed the 23 TMs@BPN and identified several SACs with high potential for efficient nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR), including Mo@BPN, V@BPN, W@BPN, and Re@BPN. Among them, Mo@BPN exhibited a low limiting potential of -0.37 V. (3) Analyzing the external trends exhibited by the screened catalysts revealed the fundamental mechanisms driving NRR activity. The exceptional NRR catalytic performance is attributed to the multiple push-pull effects between the d orbitals of TMs and the π* and p orbitals of N₂, which play a critical role in the chemisorption and activation of N₂. (4) The triangular volcano plot, composed of the free energy changes for N2 adsorption, the first protonation step, and the last protonation step of the screened catalysts, reveals the NRR activity trends. An optimal adsorption strength (moderate electron donation) can effectively balance the first hydrogenation and the last deamination steps, demonstrating high catalytic performance. These findings and conclusions provide valuable insights for designing efficient NRR electrocatalysts and inspire further experimental and theoretical studies to explore the potential applications of TMs anchored on BPN substrates in various fields. coredata.dc:description: Synthesizing efficient and selective green ideal catalysts has been an increasingly critical, yet unsolved, issue for the ammonia synthesis industry, hindering the growing global demand for environmental protection and energy efficiency. Electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction (eNRR) is a promising technology for low-energy ammonia synthesis. However, designing efficient electrocatalysts for NRR remains challenging. The emergence of graphene-like substrates offers exciting prospects for addressing this challenge and facilitating single-atom catalysts in eNRR. Here, we report the innovative selection of a recently synthesized two-dimensional biphenyl network (2D BPN) compound as a substrate. Its excellent conductivity and porosity enable stable transition metal atoms (TMs) support for constructing eNRR electrocatalysts. we evaluated the feasibility of 23 TMs anchored on BPN for eNRR by high-throughput first-principles calculations. Through a systematic five-step strategy, we identified several single-atom catalysts (SACs) with potential for eNRR, including Mo@BPN, V@BPN, W@BPN, and Re@BPN. Among them, Mo@BPN exhibited the best balance in the adsorption of key reaction intermediates (e.g., N2H and NH3) and demonstrated a low limiting potential (-0.37 V). In addition, the underlying mechanism of NRR activity was elucidated by analyzing the extrinsic patterns revealed through the screened catalysts. A triangular volcano diagram, incorporating the initial protonation step, adsorption free energy, and final protonation step, revealed the NRR activity trend. Overall, this study provides a solid theoretical foundation and valuable guidance for future experimental exploration of efficient electrocatalysts for ammonia synthesis on BPN. Crucial insights into the theoretical design of efficient electrocatalysts are also offered.
